none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Frank E. Adams, July 5, 1888
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Frank E. Adams, July 5, 1888
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 26 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

Office of
County Judge of Johnson County,
F. E. Adams,
JUDGE
Cleburne, Texas. July 5, 1888.

Prof. Louis L. McInnis,
College Station, Texas.
My dear Sir:- I am in receipt of your
circular postal.
Are you the son of Rev. Richmond McInnis,
late of Mississippi? I knew him very well
when I was a young man. More than twenty
years ago, he received me into the Communion
of the Presbyterian Church. I saw him frequently
both at my mother's and Judge McCallum's
in Jasper Co. You will please excuse me. I will try to send
you some students.

[Closing]

Very truly yours,
Frank E Adams

**My Analysis and Transcription of the Handwritten Letter** Okay, I'm ready to dive into this transcription. I see a handwritten letter and my job is to get a clean, accurate rendition of its contents, while respecting all the formatting and visual cues. First, I'm analyzing the header: it's a bit complex! I see "Office of" and "County Judge of Johnson County" in a somewhat formal gothic script, centered on the page. Then, to the right, in printed text, is "F. E. Adams" and his title, "JUDGE." Finally, there's a line that appears to be pre-printed, "Cleburne, Texas," followed by the handwritten date "July 5, 1888." I'm carefully noting how each element is presented, as this is part of the letter's overall design. Next, I move to the body. The letter is addressed to "Prof. Louis L. McInnis," and the location is "College Station, Texas." I'm scrutinizing "Texas," as the handwriting here is a little scrawled, but it definitely looks like "Texas." The salutation is "My dear Sir:-" and the body begins with "I am in receipt of your circular postal." It seems like a standard business letter. The interesting part starts on the third line: "Are you the son of Rev. Richmond McInnis," followed by an inquiry about the recipient's connection to someone the writer knew. There's a mention of the Presbyterian Church, and a location, "Jasper Co." I'm keeping a close eye on any potential ambiguities in the writing. I'm making a point to get the location "College Station, Texas." correct. Is it "Tex." or "Texas." The handwritten 's' at the end of "Texas" is a little ambiguous, but after close examination, it looks like "Texas." Then, there is the line "You will please excuse me. I will try to send" - and I'm noting the phrasing, as it suggests the writer may be a bit constrained or perhaps responding briefly. This is followed by "you some students." Finally, there is a closing "Very truly yours," followed by the signature "Frank E Adams." The signature is somewhat scrawled, so I will double check it. I'm noting the clear "F. E." and the ending, "Adams," which seems legible enough, given the rest of the handwriting in the signature. Now, as per instructions, I will generate the transcription. I'm keeping the original spelling, punctuation, and capitalization. I'm using the requested HTML tags to structure the document. The goal is a faithful, readable, and accurately formatted transcription of this letter. Here's the detailed transcription: [Header]

Office of
County Judge of Johnson County,

F. E. Adams,
JUDGE

Cleburne, Texas. July 5, 1888.

[Body]

Prof. Louis L. McInnis,
College Station, Texas.
My dear Sir:- I am in receipt of your
circular postal.
Are you the son of Rev. Richmond McInnis,
late of Mississippi? I knew him very well
when I was a young man. More than twenty
years ago, he received me into the Communion
of the Presbyterian Church. I saw him frequently
both at my mother's and Judge McCallum's
in Jasper Co. You will please excuse me. I will try to send
you some students.

[Closing]

Very truly yours,
Frank E Adams

This was wrong
Charge of 7 Cents
[Signature] G A K

It looks like we have a document that's been folded, docketed if you will, with the handwritten text on the reverse.
